canonical_explanation.text: A tissue is a group of cells that have a similar structure and function, working together as a unit. In multicellular organisms, tissues allow division of labour, making the organism more efficient. Plant tissues are broadly classified as meristematic (actively dividing, found at growing tips) and permanent (differentiated, no longer dividing). Simple permanent tissues include parenchyma (thin-walled, stores food), collenchyma (thickened corners, provides flexibility), and sclerenchyma (thick lignified walls, dead cells, provides mechanical strength). Complex permanent tissues include xylem (transports water and minerals upward) and phloem (transports food from leaves to other parts). Animal tissues are classified into four types: epithelial tissue (covers body surfaces and lines organs), connective tissue (connects and supports different organs — includes blood, bone, cartilage), muscular tissue (responsible for movement — striated, smooth, and cardiac), and nervous tissue (transmits nerve impulses via neurons).
rules: A tissue is a group of cells with similar structure and function.
Meristematic tissue is found at growth points and cells divide continuously.
Permanent tissue forms when meristematic cells differentiate and lose the ability to divide.
Parenchyma has thin cell walls, stores food, and performs photosynthesis (chlorenchyma).
Collenchyma provides flexibility with irregularly thickened corners.
Sclerenchyma has thick, lignified walls and is dead at maturity — provides mechanical strength.
Xylem transports water and minerals from roots to leaves (upward).
Phloem transports prepared food from leaves to other parts of the plant.
Epithelial tissue forms a protective covering on body surfaces and organ linings.
Connective tissue includes blood, bone, cartilage, ligament, tendon, and adipose tissue.
Striated (skeletal) muscle is voluntary; smooth (unstriated) muscle is involuntary; cardiac muscle is involuntary and found only in the heart.
Neurons are the structural and functional unit of nervous tissue.

questions.question_text: A tissue is defined as:

options.text: A single cell performing a specific function
A group of cells with similar structure and function
An organ made up of different cell types
A collection of organs working together

questions.explanation_correct: A tissue is a group of cells that are similar in structure and work together to perform a specific function. For example, muscle tissue consists of muscle cells that work together to produce movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A single cell performing a function describes a unicellular organism. An organ is made up of different tissues, not a tissue itself. A collection of organs working together is an organ system.

questions.question_text: Which type of plant tissue is responsible for growth at the tips of roots and stems?
questions.explanation_correct: Meristematic tissue is found at the growing tips (apices) of roots and stems. Its cells are actively dividing, undifferentiated, thin-walled, and have dense cytoplasm with prominent nuclei. Apical meristems are specifically responsible for growth in length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Permanent tissue has already differentiated and lost the ability to divide. Sclerenchyma is a type of permanent tissue that provides mechanical support. Phloem is a complex tissue for food transport, not growth.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of meristematic tissue?
questions.explanation_correct: Meristematic cells do NOT have large vacuoles. They have very small or no vacuoles because the cytoplasm is dense and the cell is actively dividing. Large vacuoles are a characteristic of mature, differentiated plant cells (permanent tissue).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all correct characteristics of meristematic tissue. Meristematic cells actively divide, have thin primary cell walls (no secondary wall), and contain dense cytoplasm with prominent nuclei.

questions.question_text: Intercalary meristem is found at:

options.text: The base of leaves or internodes in grasses

questions.explanation_correct: Intercalary meristem is found at the base of leaves or at the base of internodes, particularly in grasses. It helps in the elongation of internodes and is derived from apical meristem that got left behind during growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tips of roots have apical meristem. The sides of stems have lateral meristem (cambium). Seeds contain embryonic tissue but not intercalary meristem as such.

questions.question_text: Which simple permanent tissue stores food and has thin cell walls?
questions.explanation_correct: Parenchyma is a simple permanent tissue with thin cell walls and is the most common tissue in plants. It stores food, provides support through turgor, and when it contains chloroplasts (called chlorenchyma), it performs photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Collenchyma has irregularly thickened corners, not uniformly thin walls. Sclerenchyma has thick, lignified walls and is dead. Xylem is a complex tissue, not a simple permanent tissue.

questions.question_text: Which tissue provides flexibility to plant organs and has thickened corners?
questions.explanation_correct: Collenchyma is a simple permanent tissue that provides flexibility and mechanical support to growing parts of plants. It has living cells with irregularly thickened corners (due to pectin and cellulose deposition). It is found below the epidermis of stems and in leaf stalks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parenchyma has uniformly thin walls and primarily stores food. Sclerenchyma has uniformly thick walls and provides rigidity, not flexibility. Meristematic tissue is for growth, not mechanical support.

questions.question_text: Sclerenchyma tissue is made up of cells that are:
questions.explanation_correct: Sclerenchyma cells are dead at maturity. They have thick cell walls that are uniformly thickened due to deposition of lignin (a hard substance). This makes them rigid and provides mechanical strength to the plant. Examples include the hard shells of nuts and the fibre in coconut husk.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Living cells with thin walls describes parenchyma. Living cells with thickened corners describes collenchyma. Actively dividing cells describes meristematic tissue. Sclerenchyma is characterized by dead, thick-walled, lignified cells.

questions.question_text: The husk of a coconut is made of which type of tissue?
questions.explanation_correct: The husk of a coconut is made of sclerenchyma tissue. The thick, hard, lignified walls of sclerenchyma fibres give the coconut husk its tough and rigid nature. Sclerenchyma provides mechanical strength and protection to the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parenchyma is soft and thin-walled, unsuitable for the tough husk. Collenchyma provides flexibility, not the rigidity of a coconut husk. Meristematic tissue is for growth. The hardness of the coconut husk comes from sclerenchyma fibres.

questions.question_text: Parenchyma that contains chloroplasts and performs photosynthesis is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Parenchyma containing chloroplasts is called chlorenchyma. It is found in the mesophyll of leaves and green parts of stems. The chloroplasts in chlorenchyma cells carry out photosynthesis, making it essential for food production in plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aerenchyma is parenchyma with large air spaces found in aquatic plants for buoyancy. Collenchyma and sclerenchyma are different types of permanent tissue that do not specifically perform photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Which complex tissue is responsible for the transport of water and minerals from roots to leaves?
questions.explanation_correct: Xylem is the complex permanent tissue that transports water and dissolved minerals from the roots to the leaves and other aerial parts of the plant. It consists of vessels, tracheids, xylem fibres, and xylem parenchyma.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phloem transports prepared food (sugars) from leaves to other parts, not water. Parenchyma is a simple tissue for storage. Epidermis is a protective outer covering, not a transport tissue.

questions.question_text: Phloem is responsible for transporting:

options.text: Prepared food (sugars) from leaves to other parts
Carbon dioxide from roots to leaves

questions.explanation_correct: Phloem transports prepared food materials (mainly sugars like sucrose) from the leaves where they are made (by photosynthesis) to all other parts of the plant. This process is called translocation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water and mineral transport is the function of xylem, not phloem. Phloem does not transport gases like oxygen or carbon dioxide. Gas exchange occurs through stomata and lenticels.

questions.question_text: Which component of xylem is primarily responsible for the conduction of water?
questions.explanation_correct: Vessels and tracheids are the main conducting elements of xylem. Vessels are long tube-like structures formed by rows of cells with perforated end walls. Tracheids are elongated cells with tapering ends. Both are dead cells that conduct water and minerals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Xylem parenchyma stores food and assists in lateral conduction. Xylem fibres provide mechanical support. Companion cells are part of phloem, not xylem.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a component of phloem?
questions.explanation_correct: Phloem consists of sieve tubes, companion cells, phloem fibres, and phloem parenchyma. Sieve tubes are the conducting elements that transport food, and companion cells assist them in their function. Unlike xylem vessels, sieve tube elements are living cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tracheids, vessels, and xylem fibres are all components of xylem, not phloem. Phloem has its own unique components: sieve tubes, companion cells, phloem fibres, and phloem parenchyma.

questions.question_text: Which type of animal tissue forms a protective covering on body surfaces?
questions.explanation_correct: Epithelial tissue forms a protective covering on the body surfaces, lines internal organs and cavities, and forms glands. It acts as a barrier between the body and the external environment, preventing the entry of harmful substances and microorganisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Connective tissue connects and supports different organs. Muscular tissue is responsible for movement. Nervous tissue transmits nerve impulses. Only epithelial tissue specifically forms a protective covering on body surfaces.

questions.question_text: Blood is classified as which type of tissue?
questions.explanation_correct: Blood is classified as a connective tissue because it connects different parts of the body by transporting substances (oxygen, nutrients, waste, hormones) between them. It has a fluid matrix called plasma in which blood cells (RBCs, WBCs, platelets) are suspended.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blood is not epithelial tissue (which covers surfaces), muscular tissue (which produces movement), or nervous tissue (which transmits impulses). Blood is a fluid connective tissue with a liquid matrix.

questions.question_text: Which type of muscle tissue is found in the heart?
questions.explanation_correct: Cardiac muscle is found exclusively in the heart. It is involuntary (not under conscious control), striated (has light and dark bands), and its cells are branched and interconnected, allowing the heart to contract rhythmically and pump blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Striated (skeletal) muscle is attached to bones and is voluntary. Smooth muscle is found in internal organs like the stomach and intestines. Voluntary muscle is another name for skeletal muscle. Only cardiac muscle is specific to the heart.

questions.question_text: The walls of the stomach and intestines contain which type of muscle tissue?
questions.explanation_correct: The walls of the stomach and intestines contain smooth (unstriated) muscle tissue. Smooth muscle is involuntary, meaning it contracts without conscious control. It produces the peristaltic movements that push food through the digestive tract.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Striated (skeletal) muscle is attached to bones and is voluntary. Cardiac muscle is found only in the heart. Skeletal muscle is another name for striated muscle. The digestive tract contains smooth muscle for involuntary peristalsis.

questions.question_text: A neuron consists of a cell body, dendrites, and a long fibre called:
questions.explanation_correct: A neuron consists of a cell body (soma), short branching projections called dendrites (which receive signals), and a long fibre called an axon (which transmits signals away from the cell body). The axon may be covered by a myelin sheath for faster signal transmission.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A tendon connects muscle to bone. A ligament connects bone to bone. Myelin is the insulating sheath around the axon, not the fibre itself. The long fibre of a neuron is called the axon.

questions.question_text: Which connective tissue connects muscles to bones?
questions.explanation_correct: Tendons are tough, fibrous connective tissues that connect muscles to bones. They are made of strong, inelastic fibres (collagen) that transmit the force generated by muscle contraction to the bone, enabling movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ligaments connect bone to bone at joints, not muscles to bones. Cartilage provides cushioning at joints. Adipose tissue stores fat. Only tendons specifically connect muscles to bones.

questions.question_text: Lateral meristem (cambium) is responsible for:

options.text: Increase in length of the plant
Increase in thickness (girth) of the stem

questions.explanation_correct: Lateral meristem, also known as cambium, is found along the sides of the stem and root. It is responsible for secondary growth, which increases the thickness (girth) of the stem and root by adding new cells to both sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increase in length is the function of apical meristem at the tips. Leaf and flower growth involves apical and intercalary meristems. Lateral meristem specifically increases the girth of stems and roots.

questions.question_text: Which type of epithelial tissue is found in the lining of kidney tubules?
questions.explanation_correct: Cuboidal epithelium is found in the lining of kidney tubules and in salivary gland ducts. These cube-shaped cells are involved in absorption, excretion, and secretion. They provide mechanical support and help in the filtration process in kidneys.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Squamous epithelium is flat and found in blood vessels and lung alveoli. Columnar epithelium is tall and found in the intestine. Glandular epithelium forms glands. Kidney tubules specifically have cuboidal epithelium.

questions.question_text: In xylem, which cells are dead at maturity?
questions.explanation_correct: In xylem, vessels, tracheids, and xylem fibres are all dead at maturity. Their cell walls are thickened with lignin. Only xylem parenchyma remains alive. The dead, hollow vessels and tracheids form efficient tubes for water transport.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not only tracheids but also vessels and xylem fibres are dead. Xylem parenchyma is the only living component of xylem. Therefore, not all components are dead — xylem parenchyma is living.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Sclerenchyma provides mechanical strength to the plant.
Reason: Sclerenchyma cells have thin, flexible walls.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is true — sclerenchyma does provide mechanical strength. However, the reason is false — sclerenchyma cells do NOT have thin, flexible walls. They have thick, lignified (hardened) walls, which is precisely what gives them their strength. The thick walls make them rigid, not flexible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is false because sclerenchyma cells have thick, lignified walls (not thin, flexible ones). It is these thick walls that provide the mechanical strength mentioned in the assertion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct match?

options.text: Adipose tissue — fills spaces between organs and provides support
Areolar tissue — fills spaces between organs and provides support

questions.explanation_correct: Areolar tissue is a loose connective tissue that fills the spaces between organs, supports internal organs, and helps in repair. It contains fibres and cells scattered in a semi-fluid matrix. Adipose tissue is the one that stores fat, and bone has a solid matrix.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Areolar tissue fills spaces, not stores fat — that is the function of adipose tissue. Adipose tissue stores fat, not fills spaces. Bone has a hard, calcified matrix, not a fluid one. Blood is the connective tissue with a fluid matrix.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about striated, smooth, and cardiac muscles is correct?

options.text: Striated muscles are involuntary and found in internal organs
Smooth muscles are voluntary and attached to bones
Cardiac muscle is involuntary and found only in the heart
All three types of muscles are under voluntary control

questions.explanation_correct: Cardiac muscle is involuntary (not under conscious control) and is found exclusively in the heart. It has branched fibres with intercalated discs that allow coordinated rhythmic contractions for pumping blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Striated muscles are voluntary (not involuntary) and attached to bones. Smooth muscles are involuntary (not voluntary) and found in internal organs. Not all muscles are voluntary — only skeletal (striated) muscles are voluntary.

questions.question_text: Unlike xylem, all elements of phloem except phloem fibres are:
questions.explanation_correct: In phloem, sieve tubes, companion cells, and phloem parenchyma are all living cells. Only phloem fibres are dead. This is unlike xylem where most components (vessels, tracheids, xylem fibres) are dead, with only xylem parenchyma being alive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Most phloem elements are living, not dead. Phloem cells are not made of lignin — that is a characteristic of xylem. Phloem transports food, not water.

questions.question_text: The tissue that connects bone to bone at a joint is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ligaments are strong, elastic connective tissues that connect bone to bone at joints. They allow movement at joints while preventing dislocation. Ligaments are slightly elastic, unlike tendons which are inelastic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tendons connect muscle to bone, not bone to bone. Cartilage provides cushioning at joints but does not connect bones. Areolar tissue fills spaces between organs. Only ligaments connect bone to bone.

questions.question_text: Aquatic plants have large air cavities in their parenchyma to help them float. This type of parenchyma is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Aerenchyma is a type of parenchyma tissue with large intercellular air spaces. It is found in aquatic plants and helps them float by providing buoyancy. The air spaces also facilitate gaseous exchange in waterlogged conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorenchyma is parenchyma containing chloroplasts for photosynthesis. Collenchyma is a different type of tissue with thickened corners. Prosenchyma refers to elongated cells, not air-filled parenchyma.

questions.question_text: Permanent tissue is formed from meristematic tissue by the process of:
questions.explanation_correct: Permanent tissue is formed when meristematic cells undergo differentiation — they take up specific roles, develop special structures, and lose the ability to divide. This process of taking on a permanent shape, size, and function is called differentiation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell division is what meristematic tissue does; it does not convert it to permanent tissue. Fertilization is the fusion of gametes. Osmosis is the movement of water. Differentiation is the process that converts meristematic cells into permanent tissue.

questions.question_text: Squamous epithelium is found in the lining of:
questions.explanation_correct: Squamous epithelium consists of flat, thin cells that form a smooth, delicate lining. It is found in blood vessels (endothelium), lung alveoli, and the lining of the mouth. Its thin nature facilitates the diffusion of gases and nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The intestine is lined with columnar epithelium for absorption. Kidney tubules have cuboidal epithelium. The respiratory tract has ciliated columnar epithelium. Blood vessels and lung alveoli have squamous epithelium for efficient exchange.

questions.question_text: A key difference between xylem and phloem is:

options.text: Xylem transports food while phloem transports water
Xylem transport is unidirectional (upward) while phloem transport is bidirectional
Both transport water in opposite directions
Xylem is only found in roots while phloem is only in leaves

questions.explanation_correct: Xylem transports water and minerals unidirectionally from roots to aerial parts (upward). Phloem transports food bidirectionally — from leaves to roots (downward) and from leaves to growing tips (upward), depending on the plant's needs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the functions — xylem transports water, phloem transports food. Both are not involved in water transport. Both xylem and phloem are found throughout the plant, not restricted to specific parts.

questions.question_text: Which type of connective tissue has a hard, calcified matrix?
questions.explanation_correct: Bone is a connective tissue with a hard, rigid matrix due to the deposition of calcium salts (calcification). The matrix is made of collagen fibres impregnated with calcium and phosphorus compounds, making bones strong and supportive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blood has a fluid matrix (plasma). Cartilage has a firm but flexible matrix of chondrin. Adipose tissue has a soft matrix with fat-filled cells. Only bone has a hard, calcified matrix.

questions.question_text: Meristematic tissue cells are thin-walled and have dense cytoplasm.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Meristematic cells have thin primary cell walls (no secondary wall), dense cytoplasm (due to absence of large vacuoles), and prominent nuclei. These features enable rapid cell division.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Meristematic cells indeed have thin walls and dense cytoplasm. These characteristics are essential for their function of continuous cell division.

questions.question_text: Sclerenchyma cells are living at maturity and have thin cell walls.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Sclerenchyma cells are dead at maturity, not living. They have thick, lignified cell walls (not thin walls). The deposition of lignin makes the walls hard and rigid, and the cell contents are lost as the cells die.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false on both counts. Sclerenchyma cells are dead (not living) at maturity, and their walls are thick and lignified (not thin). These features give them their mechanical strength.

questions.question_text: Xylem transports food prepared by leaves to other parts of the plant.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Xylem transports water and dissolved minerals from roots to aerial parts, not food. It is phloem that transports prepared food (sugars) from leaves to other parts of the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Xylem carries water and minerals upward from roots. Phloem is the tissue responsible for transporting food from leaves to other plant parts.

questions.question_text: Cardiac muscle is a voluntary muscle that we can consciously control.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Cardiac muscle is involuntary — it contracts rhythmically on its own without conscious control. We cannot voluntarily speed up or slow down our heartbeat. Only skeletal (striated) muscles are voluntary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Cardiac muscle is involuntary, meaning it functions without conscious control. The heart beats continuously and automatically throughout life.

questions.question_text: Blood is a type of connective tissue with a fluid matrix called plasma.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Blood is classified as a connective tissue. Its matrix is plasma, which is a fluid (unlike the solid matrix of bone or the semi-solid matrix of cartilage). Blood cells — RBCs, WBCs, and platelets — are suspended in this fluid matrix.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Blood is indeed a connective tissue. Its liquid matrix is called plasma, which makes up about 55% of the blood volume and carries blood cells and dissolved substances.

questions.question_text: Collenchyma provides rigidity like sclerenchyma because both have lignified walls.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Collenchyma provides flexibility (not rigidity) and its walls are thickened with cellulose and pectin (not lignin). Only sclerenchyma has lignified walls that provide rigidity. Collenchyma cells are living; sclerenchyma cells are dead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Collenchyma provides flexibility, not rigidity. Its walls are thickened with pectin and cellulose at the corners, not lignin. Only sclerenchyma has lignified walls and provides rigidity.

questions.question_text: A group of cells that are similar in structure and work together to perform a specific function is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A tissue is defined as a group of cells having similar origin, structure, and function that work together as a unit. Different types of tissues make up organs, and organs make up organ systems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'tissue'. An organ is made of different tissues, and an organ system is made of different organs. A tissue specifically refers to a group of similar cells working together.

questions.question_text: The simple permanent tissue that has thick, lignified walls and is dead at maturity is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Sclerenchyma is the simple permanent tissue characterized by thick, lignified cell walls. The cells are dead at maturity because the thick lignin deposits block nutrient supply. It provides mechanical strength and rigidity to the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'sclerenchyma'. Parenchyma has thin walls and is living. Collenchyma has walls thickened at corners and is also living. Only sclerenchyma has uniformly thick, lignified walls and is dead at maturity.

questions.question_text: The complex plant tissue that transports water and minerals from roots to leaves is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Xylem is the complex permanent tissue that transports water and dissolved minerals from the roots to the aerial parts (leaves, stems) of the plant. It consists of vessels, tracheids, xylem parenchyma, and xylem fibres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'xylem'. Phloem transports food (not water). Xylem specifically conducts water and minerals upward from the roots.

questions.question_text: The connective tissue that connects muscle to bone is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A tendon is a tough, fibrous connective tissue that connects muscles to bones. Tendons transmit the force of muscle contraction to the bones, enabling movement. They are made of strong collagen fibres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'tendon'. A ligament connects bone to bone, not muscle to bone. Tendons specifically connect muscles to bones and enable movement.

questions.question_text: The long fibre of a neuron that carries nerve impulses away from the cell body is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The axon is the long, thread-like extension of a neuron that carries nerve impulses away from the cell body to other neurons, muscles, or glands. It can be very long — up to a metre or more in some cases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'axon'. Dendrites are the short, branching projections that receive impulses towards the cell body. The axon specifically carries impulses away from the cell body.

questions.question_text: The process by which meristematic cells take up a permanent shape, size, and function is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Differentiation is the process by which cells from meristematic tissue take up a permanent shape, size, and function. The cells lose their ability to divide and become specialized for specific roles, forming permanent tissue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'differentiation'. This is a one-way process where actively dividing meristematic cells transform into specialized permanent tissue cells.

questions.question_text: In phloem, the main conducting elements that transport food are called ___ tubes.
questions.explanation_correct: Sieve tubes are the main conducting elements in phloem. They are living cells arranged end to end, with perforated end walls (sieve plates) that allow food materials to pass through. Companion cells help sieve tubes in their function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'sieve'. Sieve tubes are named for their sieve-like perforated end walls (sieve plates). They are the primary elements through which food is transported in phloem.

questions.question_text: Which type of epithelial tissue has cilia on its surface and is found in the respiratory tract?
questions.explanation_correct: Ciliated columnar epithelium is found lining the respiratory tract (trachea, bronchi). The cilia are hair-like projections that beat in a coordinated manner to push mucus (which traps dust and germs) upward and out of the respiratory tract.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Squamous epithelium is flat and found in blood vessels. Cuboidal epithelium is cube-shaped and found in kidney tubules. Glandular epithelium forms glands. The respiratory tract has ciliated columnar epithelium for mucus clearance.

questions.question_text: Cork (bark) in older stems is made up of cells that are:

options.text: Living with thin walls and dense cytoplasm
Dead, compactly arranged, with a chemical called suberin in their walls

questions.explanation_correct: Cork cells are dead and compactly arranged without intercellular spaces. Their walls contain a waxy substance called suberin which makes them impervious to water and gases. This provides protection against water loss, mechanical injury, and pathogens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cork cells are dead, not living, so they cannot have dense cytoplasm or chloroplasts. They are not meristematic. The key feature is the presence of suberin in their walls which waterproofs the outer bark.

questions.question_text: The tip of the nose and the external ear are supported by:
questions.explanation_correct: Cartilage is a flexible connective tissue that supports the tip of the nose and the external ear (pinna). It has a firm but flexible matrix of chondrin, which allows these structures to maintain their shape while being bendable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bone is too rigid for these flexible structures. Ligaments connect bones at joints. Tendons connect muscles to bones. The flexible yet supportive nature of cartilage makes it ideal for the nose tip and ear.

questions.question_text: The process of transport of food from leaves to other parts of the plant through phloem is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Translocation is the process of transport of food (mainly sucrose) from the leaves (source) to other parts of the plant (sink) through the phloem. This process requires metabolic energy in the form of ATP.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transpiration is the loss of water vapour from leaves. Absorption is the uptake of water and minerals by roots. Assimilation is the utilization of food by cells. Translocation specifically refers to food transport via phloem.

questions.question_text: Why are plants able to grow throughout their life while animals cannot?

options.text: Plants have meristematic tissue in certain regions that keeps dividing
Plants do not have permanent tissue
All plant cells can divide continuously
Plants have a cell wall that allows unlimited growth

questions.explanation_correct: Plants can grow throughout their life because they retain meristematic tissue (at root tips, shoot tips, and lateral meristems) that continues to divide throughout the plant's life. Animals, on the other hand, have growth limited to a certain age.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants do have permanent tissue — in fact, most of the plant body is made of permanent tissue. Not all plant cells can divide; only meristematic cells can. The cell wall does not enable unlimited growth. It is the presence of meristematic tissue that allows continuous growth.
